bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Howard A. Kelly, September 10, 1906

div1.p: Carroll appeals to Kelly to consider Carroll's own statement of the facts concerning the responsibilities and actions of the Yellow Fever Board members. Carroll objects to Kean's version of the events and to Kelly's assertions in his book.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Howard A. Kelly, September 10, 1906

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
September 10th 1906.

div1.p:
The President
has recently, through his
Secretary, Mr Loeb, called
for an official statement
of the services rendered by
the various participators
in the recent work on yellow
fever, in Cuba. This request
was prompted by a review
of your book, in the Outlook
for August 11th. The letter
was referred to the Surgeon
General by General Ainsworth,
Military Secretary U.S.A., and
I was called in to discuss
the statements made in the
reply. I took exception to
several of the statements made
by Major Kean, in the reply he
had written for the Surgeon
General and, on account of the
importance of the subject, de-
clined to discuss the matter
orally, for fear of subsequent
misunderstanding or mis-in-
terpretation, I was permitted
by the Surgeon General to take
the paper and submit a
written statement on the following
morning. A copy of my state-
ment is enclosed. As there
was no evidence of intention to forward my state-
ment with the report, in which your book was
cited as authority for certain statements contained
therein; as my actual knowledge of the facts was
not considered in the preparation of your state-
ments, and as you have now been made aware of
the truth in this matter; remembering also your
kind offer when I saw you last in Baltimore,
I appeal to you to kindly see that justice
is done to myself and to my family.

I have learned, during the past six years,
that it is useless to expect justice from
Major Kean, who is incapable of writing
an unbiased account of the work. I ask
consideration only of the facts that can be
proved.

Trusting you will not regard this
letter in the light of an annoyance, I am,
